commit_message:
Don't quote {posargs} in tox.ini

Quotes around {posargs} cause the entire string to be combined into one
arg that gets passed to stestr. This prevents passing multiple args
(e.g. '--concurrency=16 some-regex')

Change-Id: Ie3379b54b354984348a10ec32bf6d245d1c04847
Closes-Bug: #1801816

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ife18281cb3f1a28d1ccc52196ca708e7ace14395
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I46218ec911a9e61959b5d36f573181efaff529c4

[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-11-01 18:29:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2018-11-02 06:48:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-11-02 11:50:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I very much like the idea, I wasn't aware that we had the ability the run per-step ansible hooks during deploy lately.

Actually tagging the docker images is already perform via ansible tasks during minor updates and major upgrades, so this makes is way cleaner if we can do the same (and even reference the tagging tasks) during deploy.

Let me update the review to include all services :)"}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-11-02 12:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Dan, yes, these tasks will also move into the tripleo-common role after this patch.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-11-02 15:01:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-11-02 18:39:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-11-04 20:45:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-11-04 22:24:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-05 11:26:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

It was nice to know about that neet deploy_steps_tasks thing, thank you for this, and for the docs update!
We were seeking for exactly that thing originally, while had been estimating alternative paths, like tagging on the host instead of a container. As a dependency patch, could we now remove podman from kolla overrides as well?'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:11:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:13:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

ack Bogdan, I'll try to remove podman from the container images when possible."}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-01 18:29:29.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: reimplement HA docker tagging with deploy_steps_tasks

This patch re-implements the initial deploy time
docker tagging to use the new deploy_steps_tasks
architecture instead of relying on running docker in docker.
This is now possible since we are using config-download by
default were as previously it was not.

The benefit here is it is simpler to implement and understand
both with Docker and Podman alike.

Change-Id: I81bc48b53068c3a5ed90266a4fd3e62bfb017835

commit_message:
Reimplement HA docker tagging

This patch re-implements the Ansible task that does the container image
tagging for Pacemaker managed services. It's using a role in
tripleo-common, so we don't duplicate the work.

Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
Depends-On: I61039cdaa6798e8ae7c918f772d863dc1b67ae02
Change-Id: I81bc48b53068c3a5ed90266a4fd3e62bfb017835

commit_message:
Remove NeutronServicePlugins from octavia environment files

There are no additional octavia specific neutron service plugins for
octavia required so this parameter should be removed from the
environment files.

Change-Id: I3da329db28701c7e9798083982953c5c9c861c50
(cherry picked from commit 2998c2119171f92aad6f2768ee3ea526f1527128)

commit_message:
Deprecate os_region_name option

Option "os_region_name" from group "placement" is deprecated. Use
option "region_name" from group "placement".

Change-Id: I662e012649e9b1fc069741123c2570087f4abb9a
Closes-Bug: #1762109

commit_message:
Deprecate auth_uri option

Option auth_uri from group keystone_authtoken is deprecated[1].
Use option www_authenticate_uri from group keystone_authtoken.

[1]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508522/

Depends-On: Ife5023bc4752cf3c2d7221f9f8772990c6bc09df
Change-Id: Ib2ea81dbecf58dd111ad947d2491e1defc3de0db
Implements: blueprint deprecate-auth-uri-option

commit_message:
Use freezerclient.client to support  v1 or v2

The python-freezerclient 2.0.0 is released now. We can directly use
freezerclinent.client to support api v1 or v2.

Change-Id: I30ad8694d137e0fab081b0f8ded842caa723c86f

commit_message:
Mark network slow test as slow

We have observed that tempest-full jobs was time out
many times.

  http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/#1783405

Based on below ethercalc, we are trying to check the slow
tests and mark them slow so that those tests will not run
as part of tempest-full job. There is other job tempest-slow
which will run these tests.

  https://ethercalc.openstack.org/dorupfz6s9qt

Compute slow tests have been marked slow in
- I2a0e154ba38c7407b41b7e986a0bf9b451c65cae

This commit mark network slow tests based on above ethercalc.

Change-Id: Ic2b3f5ea5b6885fe727a21810ddd9e17b779a1a0
Partial-Bug: #1783405

subject: Unable to retrieve list of volumes and retrieve volume snapshots
messages:
[{'account_id': 22124, 'date': '2018-11-02 09:36:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-11-05 19:19:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 27822, 'date': '2018-11-06 01:53:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-11-06 21:21:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I cannot reproduce the problem. http://paste.openstack.org/show/734304/
horizon log of cinder API calls: http://paste.openstack.org/show/734305/
Provisional -1'}, {'account_id': 22124, 'date': '2018-11-06 22:45:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As regular user not admin, They cannot retrive volume information with over v3.31 cinder api.
when i reviewed code of cinder, It returned bad request(400)
http://paste.openstack.org/show/734308/'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-11-07 04:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This sounds a configuration issue.
Cinder allows to configure allowed query parameters.

I confirmed "invalid filters exception" for non-existing string (like "foo")with a regular user (L.1 of http://paste.openstack.org/show/734318/) but "status" and "bootable" are available.

Could you check the response of resource_filters?
See L.25 of http://paste.openstack.org/show/734318/

I believe we assume 99% deployments make "status" and "bootable" available for query parameter.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-11-07 04:51:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

NOTE: The reason that I am trying to find out the root cause is because the proposed approach works for generic group case (the generic group supports was implemented before non-admin query parameter behavior. However, what can we do if the order of them are reversed? Such situation can happen easily if we support a new feature in cinder in future and your approach won't work."}, {'account_id': 22124, 'date': '2018-11-07 05:53:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I found I did not configure cinder 'resource_query_filters_file' for resource filter such as volume.
When I configure resource_query_filters_file in cinder config, It is working."}, {'account_id': 22124, 'date': '2018-11-07 05:54:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This is cinder configuration issue.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-02 09:36:49.000000000', 'message': 'Unable to retrieve list of volumes and retrieve volume snapshots

Unable to retrieve list of volumes and retrieve volume snapshots
as regular user because Horizon use cinder api over v3.31.
Cinder api version over 3.31 do not support volume and snapshot
API with specific invalid filters for non-admin users.
API will return bad reques(400).

Change-Id: Ia87ae22b7bf5e73de39ac9bbf1e94a2836aaac26
Closes-Bug: #1795320
'}]
commit_message:
Unable to retrieve list of volumes and retrieve volume snapshots

Unable to retrieve list of volumes and retrieve volume snapshots
as regular user because Horizon use cinder api over v3.31.
Cinder api version over 3.31 do not support volume and snapshot
API with specific invalid filters for non-admin users.
API will return bad reques(400).

Change-Id: Ia87ae22b7bf5e73de39ac9bbf1e94a2836aaac26
Closes-Bug: #1795320

With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24245, 'name': 'Harald Jens√•s', 'email': 'hjensas@redhat.com', 'username': 'harald.jensas'}, {'_account_id': 24828, 'name': 'Kaifeng Wang', 'email': 'kaifeng.w@gmail.com', 'username': 'wangkf'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-08-09 02:55:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-08-09 06:02:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-08-24 03:28:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2018-10-22 15:45:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Is there any reason we can't just detect what we need to do here?

The dnsmasq_interface config option tells us which interface DHCP requests are coming in on. At startup, we can check if this has a v4 or v6 address (or both). Then in the code, we can call iptables, ip6tables, or both, depending on what we find."}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-10-23 04:15:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Is there any reason we can't just detect what we need to do here?
 > 
 > The dnsmasq_interface config option tells us which interface DHCP
 > requests are coming in on. At startup, we can check if this has a
 > v4 or v6 address (or both). Then in the code, we can call iptables,
 > ip6tables, or both, depending on what we find.

It seems dhcpv6 uses 547 at server side, we may not support ipv6 simply like this patch.."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-10-29 14:28:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Seems reasonable. I think the best thing would be to check the interface(s) that we're being used on and possibly do both. Then again for all we know someone with specific needs could use this to execute a script or whatever."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-10-31 13:37:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-10-31 15:14:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-10-31 15:14:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

further discussion required since we're not addressing the port here."}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-11-01 01:21:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sure, iptables is an issue we experienced on ipv6 environment currently. Not sure if there is anything else, but my plan is to add a [DEFAULT]ip_version configuration option, this could help laying some ground work, in case more works required for ipv6.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-11-01 10:51:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

If we introduced the ip_version option, then this new option is redundant, right? I'd suggest we go down that path then."}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-11-01 12:14:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> If we introduced the ip_version option, then this new option is
 > redundant, right? I'd suggest we go down that path then.

right, there is no need to supply command like this, we use either iptables or ip6tables according to the ip version, hopefully we can determine the version later, something like jroll said."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-11-02 13:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-11-07 05:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Taking another approach: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615728/'}]

commit_message:
Support manipulating iptables filter under IPv6 network

This patch adds a configuration option ``[iptables]command`` to
specify the command used to manipulate iptables.

The default value is ``iptables`` which is backwards compatible,
to support iptables under IPv6 network, set this option to
``ip6tables``.

Change-Id: Ide669a717126457cba9a1fd97a2f681948f9dc38
Story: #1756012
Task: #11411
Closes-Bug: #1756012

commit_message:
Increase the deploy_plan timeout in tripleoclient

The time for the deploy workflow to complete has been creeping up, and
it is getting close to the 6 minute timeout in the client. This bumps
the timeout to 10 minutes.

Change-Id: Iadb7cc9ba3b62a0221109b1dacf2d764944f691a
Related-Bug: #1789680
(cherry picked from commit 9f716d8f66640c8ff89929843884dfb9638a96bb)
(cherry picked from commit 69f8b31201273e587a69ebe5ea5e0ca5af809b68)

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7 and drop the Python 3.5 unit test job.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's switch
to testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: Ia466868ee480834d28c58a2d1b1c21542a6e215a
Story: #2004073
Task: #27451

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7 and drop the Python 3.5 unit test job.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's switch
to testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: I077478f84bbbc5091ab6176dcb9ffdf6f2a8914d
Story: #2004073
Task: #27451

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
Let's switch to stestr as other projects have already moved to it.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: Ica91dc100de955bd58045e5e2f36146b48edb649

commit_message:
Update the min version of tox to 2.0

The verification comands used by tox need at least 2.0 version. This
patch aims to update tox version from 1.6 to 2.0 which should help with
local running of constraints targets.

Change-Id: I868a0618fd8d2c9632d6bcaf2cee51ab45618532

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-01 08:57:03.000000000', 'message': 'iptables-restore wait period cannot be zero

In case --wait (-w) parameter is zero, iptables-restore returns an
error.

Correct:
  [root@dev02 iptables]# iptables-restore -w 1 -W 20000 ipt

Incorrect:
  [root@dev02 iptables]# iptables-restore -w 0 -W 20000 ipt
  Option --wait-interval requires option --wait

Change-Id: I431fe6f637b963d61d81afed30a4fb1ec112d66c
Closes-Bug: #1800884
(cherry picked from commit 84a9a5ec57421718192427bac79b968729edeb3c)
'}]
commit_message:
iptables-restore wait period cannot be zero

In case --wait (-w) parameter is zero, iptables-restore returns an
error.

Correct:
  [root@dev02 iptables]# iptables-restore -w 1 -W 20000 ipt

Incorrect:
  [root@dev02 iptables]# iptables-restore -w 0 -W 20000 ipt
  Option --wait-interval requires option --wait

Change-Id: I431fe6f637b963d61d81afed30a4fb1ec112d66c
Closes-Bug: #1800884
(cherry picked from commit 84a9a5ec57421718192427bac79b968729edeb3c)

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: Id9eaa2cb2d9aa6648d6ac345029cebae96f9b37e
Closes-Bug:  #1801683

commit_message:
Set max microversion 2.35 for nova floatingip and securitygroup

Nova floatingip and securitygroup apis are deprecated from
microversion 2.36, so this is to set max_microversion 2.35
for them.

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#create-allocate-floating-ip-address
https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#create-security-group

Change-Id: Id4c42b05f2158a53b2e894f5b91bc19aeb0dc3fa
partially-implements: blueprint clear-deprecated-api

commit_message:
Fix multinode image list

If there are several images with the centos-7-latest tag, the resulting
environment file is broken. This fixes the command call to only return
one result.

Change-Id: If1c339b11e86a25b35c98c1f1e5024d1ee9e42bb

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-02 12:33:14.000000000', 'message': "Implement tripleo-container-tag role

A new Ansible role to tag containers managed by Pacemaker.
This role will be consummed by services managed by Pacemaker.

Requirements
------------

It requires Docker or Podman on the host, depending which container CLI
is used.

Role variables
--------------

- container_name: -- Name of the container image to tag.
- container_name_latest: -- Name of the tag (default: pcmklatest).
- container_cli: -- Name of the Container CLI tool (default to docker).

Example Playbook
----------------

Sample playbook to call the role:

  - name: Tag Pacemaker containers
    hosts: all
    roles:
      - tripleo-container-tag
    vars:
      container_name: haproxy
      container_name_latest: pcmklatest
      container_cli: docker

In THT, we'll consume this role for pacemaker-managed services, so we
can tag the images during the deployment, the updates and the upgrades
by using the same Ansible task.

Change-Id: I61039cdaa6798e8ae7c918f772d863dc1b67ae02
"}, {'created': '2018-11-05 14:01:02.000000000', 'message': "Implement tripleo-container-tag role

commit_message:
Implement tripleo-container-tag role

A new Ansible role to tag containers managed by Pacemaker.
This role will be consummed by services managed by Pacemaker.

Requirements
------------

It requires Docker or Podman on the host, depending which container CLI
is used.

Role variables
--------------

- container_image: -- Name of the container image to tag.
- container_image_latest: -- Name of the tag.
- container_cli: -- Name of the Container CLI tool (default to docker).

Example Playbook
----------------

Sample playbook to call the role:

  - name: Tag Pacemaker containers
    hosts: all
    roles:
      - tripleo-container-tag
    vars:
      container_image: haproxy
      container_image_latest: pcmklatest
      container_cli: docker

In THT, we'll consume this role for pacemaker-managed services, so we
can tag the images during the deployment, the updates and the upgrades
by using the same Ansible task.

Change-Id: I61039cdaa6798e8ae7c918f772d863dc1b67ae02

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
Let's switch to stestr as other projects have already moved to it.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: I8f4fb6c486641a878950e39771834c37fdde7487

commit_message:
Make onboot parameter for ifcfg configuration configurable

Currently the onboot parameter is hardcoded to YES, some
configurations need to disable it.

Change-Id: I139e8e9b2c8ff087ff1bf8daa8c902c4c0833d89
Close-Bug: 1705228

commit_message:
fixed memcached is not restarted when config changed

That's because instead of start_container we need to
use recreate_or_restart_container in handler.

Change-Id: I3bb0a4c38b9024b2e2e26bfc06cb143bb5d35317
Signed-off-by: Pavel Glushchak <pglushchak@virtuozzo.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2fde95ca0846d4f4c94abf5993cd9469f6a4058a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-04 14:42:43.000000000', 'message': 'Limit monotonic to python < 3.3

monotonic is a backport of the functionality in python 3.3 and above.
Add a version specifier so that we can stop installing it on versions of
python that have the feature.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/574372

commit_message:
Limit monotonic to python < 3.3

monotonic is a backport of the functionality in python 3.3 and above.
Add a version specifier so that we can stop installing it on versions of
python that have the feature.

Change-Id: Ib8c1bf08f5fa7463911602b0df19315907c81e04
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/574372

commit_message:
Fix senlin fake client creation

The new openstacksdk mechanism forces a keystone request to find info
about endpoints. We don't need this for fake client, so skip the
__init__ of the class.

Change-Id: I5b0d89ac57c14f982a6afa638f088d365e0e4ab8

commit_message:
remove external_network_bridge option

The external_network_bridge option is deprecated/legacy and being
removed from neutron (see I07474713206c218710544ad98c08caaa37dbf53a).
This patch removes the external_network_bridge option iniset from
devstack scripts.

Change-Id: I4d9641cc9bb83719c9af1edabb89a63c4c2b1d96

commit_message:
Install python3-saharaclient in Fedora or RedHat > 7

Fedora repo [1] has python3 packages, start consuming those.

[1] http://trunk.rdoproject.org/fedora/puppet-passed-ci/

Change-Id: I7a69a4bea5ffc297efd93b9a26d89433572e1f46

subject: Multi role RBAC validation

(17 comments)'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2018-09-29 15:21:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

Thinking about this carefully, I think this change requires a spec since it fundamentally alters Patrole architecture and authorization determination logic. This is also quite a significant change that should be split up between a few different patch sets:

* support multiple roles in policy authority
* supporting multiple roles in requirements authority
* supporting group overriding in rbac_utils

Each of which will require unit tests.'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2018-09-29 15:25:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2018-09-29 15:26:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16274, 'date': '2018-09-30 01:38:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Thinking about this carefully, I think this change requires a spec
 > since it fundamentally alters Patrole architecture and
 > authorization determination logic. This is also quite a significant
 > change that should be split up between a few different patch sets:
 > 
 > * support multiple roles in policy authority
 > * supporting multiple roles in requirements authority
 > * supporting group overriding in rbac_utils
 > 
 > Each of which will require unit tests.

First of all - whoa, Felipe, you did a lot in here!

Love the idea of splitting it into different patchsets and the spec.
My goal here was mainly to create POC to see if it's even possible within patrole.
I will carefully go thru all your comments and implement them within this patchset, and then will start step-by-step implementation according to your plan above."}, {'account_id': 16274, 'date': '2018-09-30 17:36:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 16274, 'date': '2018-09-30 17:36:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

[{'created': '2018-09-28 15:11:07.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Group based RBAC

Flow description

 - create new group
 - create roles within group with names from ``CONF.patrole.rbac_test_roles``
 - remove all roles assigned to current user
 - assign current user to group created above

 - test execution

 - assign admin role to user
 - remove user from group
 - remove precreated roles
 - remove group

Change-Id: Ia68bcbdbb523dfe7c4abd6107fb4c426a566ae9d

commit_message:
Multi role RBAC validation

This patchset replaces ``CONF.patrole.rbac_test_role`` with
``CONF.patrole.rbac_test_roles``, where instead of single role
we can specify list of roles to be assigned to test user.

Change-Id: Ia68bcbdbb523dfe7c4abd6107fb4c426a566ae9d

commit_message:
trivial: Add hacking checks to irrelevant-files in .zuul.yaml

This is to skip over hacking modifications triggering all Patrole
Zuul jobs as in [0]. Besides, Tempest also skips hacking in its
irrelevant-files [1]. Also do this for etc/.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614655/3
[1] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/da8aec9aedcac940ba1dbc3beee50f05f13af3f1/.zuul.yaml#L326

Change-Id: Iee5b634e77c2faaa36d3d19a3b56b1fec685aa7e

commit_message:
Avoid breaking python module dependencies with pip install

This would act as a fail-safe mecanism that avoid creation
of conflicts when doing pip install. It would prevent
running broken builds that fail in random places for reasons like
downgrading ansible to a version that is not supported by
other components (exampel tripleo).

Pip check was added in pip 10.0 so we asure that we have a recent
version before running check command.

Change-Id: If738de4d26c0c38404a18720fb39cd495e147346

osboxes@osboxes:~/git/nova-specs$ diff specs/ocata/approved/detach-boot-volume.rst specs/stein/approved/detach-boot-volume-stein.rst 
120,124d119
< There is a race condition identified in this bug [2] between volume
< operations and instance state changes. The same race condition will
< exist between the boot volume detach and the unshelve operations until
< that bug is fixed. That bug will be addressed by spec [3].
<

< That spec is not required for this one, but it is worth noting that this
< feature will benefit from the general bug fix dealt with there.
279,284c279

@All, thanks all for the review, in our usecase, TBO, we use device names, but as Dan mentioned in the comment, I'm not sure whether this is considered as a correct use of device name or not. Maybe we should just implement the rebuild API as in that API nova can read the bdm.is_root_volume field directly?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-09-10 14:49:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I still want clarification on the use of the device name for indicating that we're re-attaching the root volume."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-10 16:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

A few nits inline, and some questions.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-10 16:11:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)

After checking again, I think the attach/detach could be useful as it could be a common logic that can be used for rebuild/evacuate etc?'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2018-09-26 07:42:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-03 20:21:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

Two concerns from me here:

1. The ability to detach while stopped might work for the libvirt driver but I'm not convinced that is going to work for all virt drivers - so how is that going to be handled? I'd either omit it from this spec since it's complicated (as noted in the alternatives section already), or it would need to be somehow handled on a per-virt driver basis - but when the instance is shelved offloaded you don't know what virt driver it'd be on anyway....

2. This is very light on details about how the BDM.attachment_id, which when it was created was for the existing root volume, is going to be dealt with when you swap the root volume while the instance is shelved offloaded. Will we create a new empty attachment in the API for the new root volume and then update the BDM.attachment_id (and delete the old attachment record for the old root volume?)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-03 20:29:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-03 20:37:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-03 20:44:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2018-10-09 02:01:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(8 comments)

Thanks alot for the review, as I was out for one week for national holiday, so I didn't reply, I will update this today."}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2018-10-09 09:24:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-16 16:35:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

A couple of things inline:

1. The detach/attach flow for a shelved offloaded instance is clear wrt what happens with the root BDM record, but that's not clear for a stopped instance where the nova-compute service will delete the root BDM record unless we're going to change that logic. That would also indicate that we have an upgrade impact for detaching the root volume from a stopped instance, in other words the API shouldn't allow it for instances running on older compute services that aren't aware of this API change.

2. I think you can remove the specific mention of the libvirt driver as the only thing to be implemented for this spec. As noted inline, I'm not aware of any virt-driver specific changes needed for this spec, it's all orchestration either in the API or compute service."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-16 16:37:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-16 16:38:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2018-10-18 08:00:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-10-18 08:52:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I have couple of questions inline.
Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-18 12:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2018-10-19 07:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-10-19 15:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(4 comments)

My concerns were answered. LGTM'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-19 23:00:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

(4 comments)

Question/concern inline about swapping the root volume on a stopped instance, but I also don't really think it should be an issue, but I guess we'll see. I think this is probably good enough for a spec at this point and we'll flush any other issues out during implementation. I'd definitely like others more knowledgeable how volume attach flows in nova, like lyarwood/mdbooth, to review this and make sure I'm not missing something."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-19 23:04:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-19 23:07:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6062, 'date': '2018-10-22 05:06:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-23 15:23:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

There might be another application for detaching/attaching a root volume in a stopped instance:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/532410/

That is the spec to support rescuing volume-backed instances. I've provided an alternative workflow in that spec which depends on the support being added in this spec."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-10-23 17:20:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(2 comments)

A couple grammar nits, but those can be fixed up later'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-10-23 17:49:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)

+1 looks reasonable to me

This was approved while I was reviewing, so just leaving my comments here.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-06 23:57:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Here is something else I just thought of: it is possible to attach/detach volumes from a resized server:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c295e395d/nova/compute/api.py#L4242

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c295e395d/nova/compute/api.py#L4352

What would happen if we resized a volume-backed server, detached its root volume while it was in VERIFY_RESIZE status, and then tried to confirm/revert the resize? Would it blow up?'}]

commit_message:
Detach and attach boot volumes - Stein

It is sometimes useful for a cloud user to be able to
detach and attach the boot volume of an instance that
is not running. Currently Nova does not allow this and
some operations assume it does not happen. This spec
proposes allowing the detach and attach of boot volumes
in the shelved_offloaded and powered_off states.

There is a previously approved spec in Mitaka, Newton and
Ocata, but it only includes the change for shelved instances,
this spec append that proposal by adding also the powered_off
state.

Co-Authored-By: Andrea Rosa <andrea.rosa@hpe.com>

blueprint detach-boot-volume

Change-Id: Ide993b5ee0dba08b0ed9d641f6b96b344bb14f27

commit_message:
Add 'bionic' to supported distro

OpenStack gate jobs will be migrated to Ubuntu 18.04 Bionic
soon.

Same was added in Rocky release [1] but not for older stable branches
which cause failure when testing the bionic for stable branch jobs[2]

This commit adds bionic as supported distro for stable branches also.
[1] https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/stable/rocky/stack.sh#L224
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/72/611572/1/check/tempest-full-queens/7cd3f21/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-11-01_09_57_07_551538

Change-Id: I5ba13da1b96eca225d20d356d434e5a0a13db46c

commit_message:
For ironic-pxe use syslinux-tftpboot package instead of syslinux

For portability, the syslinux-tftpboot package should be used instead of
syslinux as it contains the same tftp server content and can be used
on both x86_64 and ppc architectures.

Change-Id: I9fd50e5312327da828d32e37a3ecf5e290485ca1
Closes-Bug: 1801824

commit_message:
Show snapshots list correctly when launching instance

In launch instance modal, when a user selects 'Instance Snapshots',
not all snapshots are listed. The snapshots which are created from
an instance with new volume or an instance created from volume
or volume snapshot don't have 'image_type' but 'block_device_mapping'.
So, judging only by image_type is not enough.

Change-Id: I7e175b6a7260ca3d82560427a8f742f8cfa35565
Closes-Bug: #1627619

commit_message:
kolla-build: Wrap tpl_dict.keys() in a list()

In python 3, tpl_dict.keys() returns a dict_keys object that does not
support indexing and is then indexed.
Wrap tpl_dict.keys() in a list() so it can be be indexed in python 2 and
3.

Change-Id: I17e3bbfc4eeba58e4bdd7fdd1ecdb21baa5c4461

commit_message:
Remove path work around for kibana

Kibana 5 shares a common path across distros now, so this workaround is
no longer required.

Change-Id: Ib922bb4b44a31ae41dcc405d5bdcc37b4011cfa5

[{'created': '2018-10-30 19:16:12.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unnecessary package install duplication

Currently the devel packages are installed everywhere,
but they only need to be where the wheels are built.

Also, there is already a task to install the packages
needed on the target hosts when installing - so we do
not need to give the same list to the venv install role
because they will already have been installed.

Change-Id: I59394c17c8a5475cc41b583268e45df1da561e7d

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary package install duplication

Currently the devel packages are installed everywhere,
but they only need to be where the wheels are built.

Also, there is already a task to install the packages
needed on the target hosts when installing - so we do
not need to give the same list to the venv install role
because they will already have been installed.

Change-Id: I59394c17c8a5475cc41b583268e45df1da561e7d

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary package install duplication

Currently the devel packages are installed everywhere,
but they only need to be where the wheels are built.

Also, there is already a task to install the packages
needed on the target hosts when installing - so we do
not need to give the same list to the venv install role
because they will already have been installed.

Finally, we remove the unnecessary installation of the
compiling packages because the python venv build role
already does it.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/613585
Change-Id: I78a0df7ba62b59ea63ddceb76d47c9422235b9f3

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary package install duplication

Currently the devel packages are installed everywhere,
but they only need to be where the wheels are built.

Also, there is already a task to install the packages
needed on the target hosts when installing - so we do
not need to give the same list to the venv install role
because they will already have been installed.

Change-Id: Ifdff299a81cbba90cf819c9a628650c8b1be3d6a

commit_message:
only write the candidate list page when the election is in progress

This is a partial fix for the fact that the candidate list does not
appear in any toctree. It disables generating the list page so that
outside of election season (like now) we can enable the sphinx flag to
treat warnings as errors.

Change-Id: Icc308470b660a7336efe5f648ac28233efadad80
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Improve error message check in tests
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-04 10:28:08.000000000', 'message': 'Improve error message check in tests

To prevent cases when a small change in error
message breaks tests, e.g.
"Disk image size is too small" was changed to
"Flavor's disk image size is smaller then ..."

Current way of checking compares whole sentences.
The new way is based on keywords comparison.

Change-Id: I44015bbbb9d02eb043520e134a6c0f1f41091b28
Signed-off-by: Dariusz Krol <d.krol@samsung.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Improve error message check in tests

To prevent cases when a small change in error
message breaks tests, e.g.
"Disk image size is too small" was changed to
"Flavor's disk image size is smaller then ..."

Current way of checking compares whole sentences.
The new way is based on keywords comparison.

Change-Id: I44015bbbb9d02eb043520e134a6c0f1f41091b28
Signed-off-by: Dariusz Krol <d.krol@samsung.com>

[{'created': '2018-11-05 16:41:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix developer config dir flask aftermath

Before flask, the code that checked for a local developer environment
config file lived in keystone/server/wsgi.py, and checked for configs at
../../.. relative to itself. Now it lives in
keystone/server/flask/core.py but still checks the same directory depth,
leaving it one short. This patch adds another directory level to the
possible_topdir path so that the wsgi application will correctly look in
keystone/etc instead of keystone/keystone/etc.

Change-Id: If1c8d7c9bb1ea7d2642ab5c5e7f92adec33bf1f2

leaving it one short. This patch adds another directory level to the

commit_message:
Fix developer config dir flask aftermath

Before flask, the code that checked for a local developer environment
config file lived in keystone/server/wsgi.py, and checked for configs at
../../.. relative to itself. Now it lives in
keystone/server/flask/core.py but still checks the same directory depth,
leaving it one short. This patch adds another directory level to the
possible_topdir path so that the wsgi application will correctly look in
keystone/etc instead of keystone/keystone/etc.

Change-Id: If1c8d7c9bb1ea7d2642ab5c5e7f92adec33bf1f2
(cherry picked from commit 9420fcca426ed18fdfc8568ab3c6025591890642)

commit_message:
Delete PKI middleware debugging section

We don't support PKI tokens in keystone any more and are in the process
of removing support for it from keystonemiddlware. Delete the outdated
information.

[{'created': '2018-11-05 10:15:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix uwsgi --http flag

In b2292e2 we changed the uwsgi example to use --http-socket, but
actually --http is supported and is correct for our usage[1]. This patch
changes it back.

commit_message:
Fix uwsgi --http flag

In b2292e2 we changed the uwsgi example to use --http-socket, but
actually --http is supported and is correct for our usage[1]. This patch
changes it back.

[1] https://uwsgi-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/HTTP.html

Change-Id: I52f208769d4deb16972038a815ce4c5e8f9bb800

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-06 09:04:29.000000000', 'message': 'iptables-restore wait period cannot be zero

In case --wait (-w) parameter is zero, iptables-restore returns an
error.

Correct:
  [root@dev02 iptables]# iptables-restore -w 1 -W 20000 ipt

Incorrect:
  [root@dev02 iptables]# iptables-restore -w 0 -W 20000 ipt
  Option --wait-interval requires option --wait

Change-Id: I431fe6f637b963d61d81afed30a4fb1ec112d66c
Closes-Bug: #1800884
(cherry picked from commit 84a9a5ec57421718192427bac79b968729edeb3c)
'}]
commit_message:
iptables-restore wait period cannot be zero

In case --wait (-w) parameter is zero, iptables-restore returns an
error.

Correct:
  [root@dev02 iptables]# iptables-restore -w 1 -W 20000 ipt

Incorrect:
  [root@dev02 iptables]# iptables-restore -w 0 -W 20000 ipt
  Option --wait-interval requires option --wait

Change-Id: I431fe6f637b963d61d81afed30a4fb1ec112d66c
Closes-Bug: #1800884
(cherry picked from commit 84a9a5ec57421718192427bac79b968729edeb3c)

I'm trying to figure out the best way to test it. I think the best answer is really a tempest test. We overload the generic 404 response with a 418 response in our test suite.

With that said, I think I know how to confirm this is working.... I'll propose a followup with a new test *or* a test to tempest to hit <keystone_url>/uuid() to ensure we return a 404 as expected (non-jsonified)"}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-10-31 11:02:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

A tempest test would be great.

Is that maybe why we didn't catch this before? It seems really unideal that we cant just have a unit test do test_client.get(/foobar, expected_status=404).

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-10-31 19:41:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-10-31 23:46:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > > answer is really a tempest test.

 > > We overload the generic 404
 > > response with a 418 response in our test suite.

 > Is that maybe why we didn't catch this before? It seems really
 > unideal that we cant just have a unit test do test_client.get(/foobar,
 > expected_status=404).

 > > I'll propose a followup with a new test *or* a test to tempest to
 > > hit <keystone_url>/uuid() to ensure we return a 404 as expected
 > > (non-jsonified)

For the case of the 418, it is specifically geared towards ensuring our tests do not hit a url that is not routed and get a 404 back where the reason for the 404 is unrouted url vs a resource not found.

I think my test has gotten around the problem. We should still have a tempest test for this as well."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-11-02 13:43:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-11-06 17:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Unregister "Exception" from flask handler

Unregister the default Exception from the flask error handler. This
is to allow flask 404 to bubble up outside of test cases normally with
out raising a 500 error.

Change-Id: I2159952acae0234472ee3fea7f387278cbefa6c3
Closes-Bug: #1800124

commit_message:
Drop strict-order flag from dnsmasq invocation

Without this flag, dnsmasq prefers to ask the servers that
are known to be up, rather than hitting servers that are either
down or known to be broken. This greatly reduces responsivity
impact of broken upstream servers.

Closes-Bug: #1746000
Change-Id: Ieee4dafc578c3bda0935fcdb80faad6c342a10e9
(cherry picked from commit d3c69dc4f22ef96ad3fb66430ce703d9c2199d2e)

commit_message:
Trivial: add reminder to update Tempest's scheduler_enabled_filters

With [1] now a thing, we should strive to keep Tempest's default for
scheduler_enabled_filters the same as Nova's enabled_filters. This
patch adds a comment to that effect.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570207/

Related-bug: 1628443
Change-Id: I0a02acb831d00b472b9d80b4f4205a7f1476feb5

commit_message:
Revert "Remove Jeremy Stanley as an official"

This reverts commit 001e13c2885ff4e4e7eabde4a22ccc0658004d9a.

Now that an election in which I was a candidate has passed, I'm
happy to volunteer to assist as an official in further elections for
the coming year.

Change-Id: I0f1eaa323aa753b318731ced4b9021d141792e89

subject: Adding Rodolfo Pacheco candidacy for TC
messages:
[{'account_id': 19064, 'date': '2018-09-07 00:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-09-07 00:08:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-09-07 00:15:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This candidacy came in after the deadline.  While it describes a valid candidate we can't accept this self nomination.

Also Welcome new contributor!"}, {'account_id': 6088, 'date': '2018-09-07 00:21:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Sadly, this has come in just after we've closed nominations.  Despite not appearing on the ballot, please consider participating in the campaign period and in discussion and reviews of governance changes.  As noted in your platform, your background and perspective differs from many of our candidates, and I believe your voice in these discussions would be a useful addition.

I look forward to being able to confirm your self-nomination for the next cycle."}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2018-11-06 21:15:55.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

The elections have concluded.'}]

commit_message:
Adds option to enable ARA plugin install

Adds the option to enable ARA callback plugin install
during bootstrap-ansible.  Set to false by default in
the bootstrap-ansible script and can be enabled with
the SETUP_ARA variable.  In the gate-check-commit,
installation is set to enabled by default.

Change-Id: I5eb4285100207a8b8808b5000261f70c89c69de2

commit_message:
Use python3 for functional tests

Switch to python3 for the tox basepython and for the devstack setup for
functional tests to fulfill the python3-first goal[1]. We still have
unit test coverage for python2.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: If82196ce6a2fffe6a43bb59077c6bdd712276958

[{'created': '2018-10-23 08:34:49.000000000', 'message': 'playbooks: Use --upgrade-strategy option for openSUSE distributions

This is a variation of 483e3a7a6ff2186b68b00c29b35213bee8074ebe ("Fix
for proper installation"). PIP >= 10 gets really upset if one is mixing
distro and pip packages and openSUSE is being hit by this problem in the
gates. As such, lets use --upgrade-strategy only-if-needed for openSUSE
by default until we can properly isolate the bifrost installation into
its own virtual environment.

Change-Id: Idac094ecc749250f023dd49b2ad9cd220158f248

commit_message:
playbooks: Use --upgrade-strategy option for openSUSE distributions

This is a variation of 483e3a7a6ff2186b68b00c29b35213bee8074ebe ("Fix
for proper installation"). PIP >= 10 gets really upset if one is mixing
distro and pip packages and openSUSE is being hit by this problem in the
gates. As such, lets use --upgrade-strategy only-if-needed for openSUSE
by default until we can properly isolate the bifrost installation into
its own virtual environment.

Change-Id: Idac094ecc749250f023dd49b2ad9cd220158f248

commit_message:
Remove paste references on keystone deployments

Keystone paste file was recently removed[1] so we should not have to
use it anymore

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/commit/d04bb1e7e61a39404b27ecf5248a0b7982863043

Change-Id: I80e2a75e427b98d73cbbe0c758df5d5eb1c6ade9

commit_message:
Support deploying storm worker and storm nimbus separately

This allows storm worker and nimbus services to be deployed on
separate hosts.

Change-Id: Icb990d289fbfb4d8f782c255fc50d092964384f7

commit_message:
Allow the networking_ansible plugin to set manage_vlans

This is required if neworks already exist and the driver
doesn't need too (or can't) create them.

Change-Id: Iff08440feb5727d436514ceaf072faed7fcdf763

XtraBackup tool.

Install XtraBackup from Percona's repos, ensuring that packages from

Include a script which invokes XtraBackup with the appropriate
options for either a full or incremental backup.

commit_message:
Introduce Percona XtraBackup image

blueprint database-backup-recovery

Implements an image suitable for taking MariaDB backups via Percona's
XtraBackup tool.

Install XtraBackup from Percona's repos, ensuring that packages from
this source aren't used for any other purpose.

Include a script which invokes XtraBackup with the appropriate
options for either a full or incremental backup.

Change-Id: Ifebe2045e5815c573c0a2ae05951c428c3f06a92

commit_message:
Monasca specific config for Fluentd

This commit adds some filters which format logs so that they
can be correctly sent to the Monasca Log API by the Monasca
Fluentd plugin. In the future the Fluentd plugin could be
extended and this config could be removed.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I87b6dfb3052d03f87349d30b66078c39d625195d

commit_message:
Switch to "tox -e docs"

Use the new PTI docs building commands, these use "tox -e docs" for
building, also update the publishing job.

Update tox.ini to use sphinx-build directly as documented in the PTI.

Note that we have to disable warnings, otherwise building fails with:
doc/source/results/ocata/ptl.rst:3:Duplicate explicit target name: "tony breeds (tonyb)".
Be aware that with current pbr and Sphinx, warnings are disabled due to
change of parameter names - so, this keeps the status quo.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/615501
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/615637
Change-Id: I4713f3a25e08056b7bce9812fa2cf62119330fcc

[{'created': '2018-09-25 16:53:49.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Support deploying the Monasca Agent

The Monasca Agent collects metrics and in this change is deployed
across the control plane. These metrics are collected into an OpenStack
project. It supports configuring a small number of plugins, which can
be extended in later commits. It makes the Monasca Agent credentials
available to other roles, such as the common role which will forward
logs to the same OpenStack project in a future commit.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I76b34fc5e1c76407a45fcf272268d5798b473ca2

commit_message:
Support deploying the Monasca Agent

The Monasca Agent collects metrics and in this change is deployed
across the control plane. These metrics are collected into an OpenStack
project. It supports configuring a small number of plugins, which can
be extended in later commits. It also makes the Monasca Agent credentials
available to other roles, such as the common role to allow forwarding
logs to Monasca.

Partially-Implements: blueprint monasca-roles
Change-Id: I76b34fc5e1c76407a45fcf272268d5798b473ca2

subject: Add optional python3.7 unit test enablement to python3-first
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5046, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'email': 'lbragstad@redhat.com', 'username': 'ldbragst'}, {'_account_id': 6547, 'name': 'Andreas Jaeger', 'email': 'jaegerandi@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaegerandi'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 10608, 'name': 'Matthew Edmonds', 'email': 'edmondsw@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'edmondsw'}, {'_account_id': 11536, 'name': 'hongbin', 'email': 'hongbin034@gmail.com', 'username': 'hongbin'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11805, 'name': 'Corey Bryant', 'email': 'corey.bryant@canonical.com', 'username': 'coreycb'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26458, 'name': 'Brin Zhang', 'email': 'zhangbailin@inspur.com', 'username': 'zhangbailin'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 19:24:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-15 19:26:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Not sure if we want to say "or". It seems like if we are going to have 3.7 optional, we should at least make 3.6 mandatory. Having a mix of some supporting 3.6 and some supporting 3.7 exclusively has potential to lead to problems.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 19:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ok so worded more to say one of them is required, but not both.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 19:30:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Are you saying all unit tests should have py36 mandatory and py37 optionally?'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-15 19:31:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, if we're not going to make 3.7 mandatory, I think we need to at least make 3.6 so."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 19:32:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think that's part of the problem though, at least from an infra pov is that we can't run 2.7, 3.5, 3.6, and 3.7."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-10-15 19:55:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We need some input from infra on this. According to [1] they were anticipating that everyone would transition off 3.5 this cycle.

1: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135659.html'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-15 20:49:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> Not sure if we want to say "or". It seems like if we are going to have 3.7 optional, we should at least make 3.6 mandatory.

Technically it was your idea ;)

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135658.html'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 22:18:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 22:18:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-16 13:16:10.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to py37-job'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-16 13:37:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-16 16:18:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

OK, based on more discussion, we declare support for the current Ubuntu LTS and CentOS stable at the start of a development cycle and their supported, packaged versions of Python. Right now, that means 2.7 and 3.6. So I think we need to state that 3.6 is a must and 3.7 is optional.

Then to conserve gate resources somewhat, I think mentioning 3.7 may be run would be good, but it would also be good to recommend those be run as experimental jobs so not every patch runs all runtimes, only the required ones to be supported.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-16 16:40:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Sean, would that scenario have voting py37 tests if they're not run on every patch?"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-16 17:25:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

No, since py37 would then be considered just preparation for a future release where it becomes a requirement, I think it would best be a non-voting job to just provide early feedback. Then when it does become a requirement, hopefully any issues with it have already been identified and there won't be any issue with moving off of 3.6 to 3.7 as the voting job."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-16 17:37:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Unfortunately if it's non-voting I don't really see the point in making the effort to enable unit tests, because the reality is (at least from my experience) if it's not voting it's ignored.

I'm in a tough position, unfortunately, as next week we will start working on stein for ubuntu 19.04 and it will be python3.7 only."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-17 18:03:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Sean, What if we were to enable non-voting py37 unit tests (run on every patch) for the subset of projects that we know are failing and skip all that are successful for now? I don't have a count on the number of projects that would include but percentage wise this might give a little bit of an idea: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:py37-job+(status:open+OR+status:merged)"}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-10-17 19:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-17 20:46:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1

(3 comments)

These changes aren't taking into account that we have limited test nodes. We can't add _all_ the python versions (as tempting as that might be).

Therefore we need to choose a focus.

I want us to test on just one python 3 and would prefer that be 3.7. If for some reason we can't do that, then 3.6. We should be moving away from 3.5 asap."}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-10-17 20:57:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-18 00:08:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

> These changes aren't taking into account that we have limited test nodes.

The entire motivation of this patch was to take into account that we have limited test nodes.

> If we are recommending one version, it should be the version that will be in common use at the end of the cycle.

In the world of Python 3 there is never just one version that is in common use at any given point, and there probably never will be. The situation with Python 2 was an anomaly, because there hasn't been a Python 2 minor release in 8 years.

This proposal is essentially saying that we'll run unit tests only on the oldest and newest versions of Python 3 that we want to support. Unfortunately this does mean running 3 sets of unit test jobs in the interim until we drop 2.7 support. After that, it will drop back to 2 sets, which is the status quo (currently 2.7 & 3.5). Just treating 2.7 as the minimum version and 3.7 as the maximum version was considered and rejected: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135783.html"}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-18 13:51:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-18 13:53:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I've read through all the comments and resubmitted this change. I understand this version doesn't take into account all feedback and that's because it can't unfortunately because there are differing opinions. I went with the approach that is the least intrusive at this point in time."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-10-18 21:33:33.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from py37-job to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-24 19:37:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1

Given the stage we're at in the release cycle, this seems like a good compromise to me - try to get as much as possible to 3.7 without requiring it. The concept of skipping 3.6 tests as long as 3.5 and 3.7 are tested is consistent with the general approach I've just proposed in If80a24766427be468b5d17f7ccac5bb7ccaa1cf4."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-25 10:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1

This seems a reasonable compromise that provides at least some degree for forward movement.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-25 12:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I still am not entirely comfortable with the phrasing here. The commit title is good to me - making 3.7 optional - but the phrasing in the update says either 3.6 or 3.7 when I think we need to state 3.6 is required and 3.7 is optional. Unless or until we change our supported platforms, we need to support 3.6 for stein for sure.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-25 12:57:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Sean, That's a good point and would align better with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/613145/. Adding non-voting py37 jobs on top of the voting py36 jobs in the current cycle would align better."}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-10-25 22:34:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-26 11:59:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-26 13:13:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-26 13:15:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

Excellent, I really like the wording of this one better. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-26 14:35:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

(1 comment)

This also works for me.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-28 22:59:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

We have previously had feedback from project teams that changing the goals after they are approved causes confusion and frustration because it seems we are moving the goal posts after the planning for the cycle has been done.

If adding the job is optional, do we need it to be part of the goal?'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2018-10-29 08:36:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-29 12:50:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> We have previously had feedback from project teams that changing
 > the goals after they are approved causes confusion and frustration
 > because it seems we are moving the goal posts after the planning
 > for the cycle has been done.
 > 
 > If adding the job is optional, do we need it to be part of the
 > goal?

That's a fair point. @Sean @Zane what do you think?"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-29 13:10:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

The thing I like about adding this is that it is entirely optional - so we shouldn't be giving the impression that we are moving the goal posts on anyone - and it will increase visibility and awareness to folks. So while there is no weight behind it as a goal requirement, my hope is it would at least raise awareness and possibly stimulate some to start preparing for the future sooner rather than later.

I'm fine if we don't add this to the goal and just try to push it through the ML and other avenues, but I see more pros than cons with doing this now."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-29 13:48:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> The thing I like about adding this is that it is entirely optional
 > - so we shouldn't be giving the impression that we are moving the
 > goal posts on anyone - and it will increase visibility and
 > awareness to folks. So while there is no weight behind it as a goal
 > requirement, my hope is it would at least raise awareness and
 > possibly stimulate some to start preparing for the future sooner
 > rather than later.
 > 
 > I'm fine if we don't add this to the goal and just try to push it
 > through the ML and other avenues, but I see more pros than cons
 > with doing this now.

Also a fair point. Additionally from my pov just being able to point somewhere to say it's "official" that we can enable non-voting py37 unit tests is useful.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-30 15:23:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote-1

I agree it is important to document the versions we're going to test with. I think modifying this goal document is the wrong way to do that. I like the idea of having it handled separately in something like https://review.openstack.org/#/c/611080/ instead."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-11-02 19:10:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote-1

(1 comment)

I agree with Doug's comments. Additionally, I think adding option criteria for the goal is going to be hard to parse after the release goes out the door."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-11-05 12:47:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:09:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-11-05 18:02:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-05 18:08:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

I think it is best to encourage 3.7 tests, even if that means some people won't do it until later.

The longer we wait, the further we get behind. It's optional. It's good to encourage people."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-11-05 19:39:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-11-05 20:27:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-11-05 20:42:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-11-05 21:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-11-05 21:14:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-11-05 21:25:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-11-06 18:30:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I question whether we need this here at all. Projects can do the change without this. You add this to a list of Completion criteria - which makes it even as an optional target part of a mandatory list.

If we add this, we should add that also explicitly that python 3.5 is not running (currently not mentioned). From the initial discussion, there were people proposing running three versions of python 3 - which puts an undue resource increase on our already busy resources. Thus, I prefer a proposal like https://review.openstack.org/613145 .

So, I give a -1: Either do it without this goal - or make it a separate goal but don't piggypack on this one."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-11-06 18:42:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Andreas, Just to be clear is that a hard -1 from infra on enabling 3 x py3 unit tests at the same time per project?'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-11-06 18:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I do not speak for Infra - I speak for myself ;)

Since I was asked on IRC to clarify my -1, it is:

"So, I give a -1: Either do it without this goal - or make it a separate goal but don't piggypack on this one."'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-11-06 19:23:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks everyone for the input and discussion on this. I've moved back to the ML for a +1 on enabling a subset of py37 unit tests in stein. Please see: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-November/136337.html"}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-11-06 19:23:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add optional python3.7 unit test enablement to python3-first

Update the Stein python3-first goal to encourage enablement of Python 3.7
unit tests.

This was discussed in further detail on the mailing list at:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135749.html

Change-Id: I007a0bc78c23c9370125490470485dd9cdf0ca8b

commit_message:
[WIP] Override sitepackages var for tox tempestenv

Since 'all-plugin' is deprecated[0] in Tempest, but some projects,
like Patrole, need access to global packages.
Modify tox.ini to use TEMPESTENV_SITEPACKAGES environment variable for
overriding `[tempestenv] sitepackages` option.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/9b4c50cf634cbea6e6a7353fff14c2f0a7ab1aa2/tox.ini#L64

Change-Id: If252cfeac119246289f2c8cc8cfe0b07c58b6bff

commit_message:
Change BFV job to use ipxe interface

As Nova's CI jobs can call the ironic-tempest-dsvm-bfv job,
it seemed to only make sense to keep that job name and have it
leverage the ipxe boot interface instead.

The newer named job, ironic-tempest-dsvm-ipxe-bfv only exists
in the ironic repository according to codesearch.openstack.org.

This removes one un-necessary check in the ironic check gate.

Change-Id: I55bd2e7e5fa5d10ca6ed3093ebabf7dc3be07fb9

subject: Assures that wrapping on PRE occurs on any kind of characters
messages:
[{'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2018-10-25 17:18:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-10-26 14:51:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7069, 'date': '2018-10-31 02:12:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I'd like to get some more opinions if this is something we want. ie, we want to display the logs as they exist, and if that includes long lines with horizontal scrolling then so be it. However, these files are marked up and if the user wants the raw logs they can still get them (usually). In other words, I think this is a good change, but only a +1 for now."}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-11-06 17:45:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

> I'd like to get some more opinions if this is something we want.
 > ie, we want to display the logs as they exist, and if that includes
 > long lines with horizontal scrolling then so be it. However, these
 > files are marked up and if the user wants the raw logs they can
 > still get them (usually). In other words, I think this is a good
 > change, but only a +1 for now.

I think that we are getting line breaks as is, they just only break on word boundaries? This will break at the screen width limit regardless of where in the word that is.

I'm willing to try it. As you say this doesn't change the original data which can still be found and if we revert this change for any reason the original data is still there without wraps."}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2018-11-06 18:31:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks!'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-25 17:18:42.000000000', 'message': 'Assures that wrapping on PRE occurs on any kind of characters

Fixes problem where some lines, like pip requirements were not wrapped
because they didn contain any white-space.

This prevents the need to use horizontal browser scrolling, even
on huge screens.

Change-Id: Ia8e32195fc8d9ca5e171506f03099ebc03859bd1
'}]
commit_message:
Assures that wrapping on PRE occurs on any kind of characters

Fixes problem where some lines, like pip requirements were not wrapped
because they didn contain any white-space.

This prevents the need to use horizontal browser scrolling, even
on huge screens.

Change-Id: Ia8e32195fc8d9ca5e171506f03099ebc03859bd1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-25 20:17:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Galera self-signed SSL functionality

Ensure that `galera-req.pem` is removed when
`galera_ssl_self_signed_regen` is enabled. When this file is not
removed, the "Create galera ssl request" task does not run again, which
is required to create a new CSR and private key.

Copy the correct files to non-bootstrap Galera nodes, which are:
- CA certificate
- Private key for CSR
- Signed certificate

Rename a few variables for clarity between private key and certificate.

Change-Id: I3c65ff93498dde97e93fe9ac46ecee894a45c3e1
'}, {'created': '2018-10-26 17:05:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Galera self-signed SSL functionality

Ensure that `galera-req.pem` is removed when
`galera_ssl_self_signed_regen` is enabled. When this file is not
removed, the "Create galera ssl request" task does not run again, which
is required to create a new CSR and private key.

Copy the correct files to non-bootstrap Galera nodes, which are:
- CA certificate
- Private key for CSR
- Signed certificate

Rename a few variables for clarity between private key and certificate.

Change-Id: I3c65ff93498dde97e93fe9ac46ecee894a45c3e1
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Galera self-signed SSL functionality

Ensure that `galera-req.pem` is removed when
`galera_ssl_self_signed_regen` is enabled. When this file is not
removed, the "Create galera ssl request" task does not run again, which
is required to create a new CSR and private key.

Copy the correct files to non-bootstrap Galera nodes, which are:
- CA certificate
- Private key for CSR
- Signed certificate

Rename a few variables for clarity between private key and certificate.

Change-Id: I3c65ff93498dde97e93fe9ac46ecee894a45c3e1

[{'created': '2018-11-02 17:22:37.000000000', 'message': 'Use extend-ignore in preference to ignore

The behavior of flake has changed so that ignore overwrites the
default list. This uses the new extend-ignore option to emulate
the old behavior.

See: https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/issues/466 for more details.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ib96a176f6cbbf485ad5b0ff2ab90e3bb8bc99abd
'}]
commit_message:
Use extend-ignore in preference to ignore

The behavior of flake has changed so that ignore overwrites the
default list. This uses the new extend-ignore option to emulate
the old behavior.

See: https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/issues/466 for more details.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ib96a176f6cbbf485ad5b0ff2ab90e3bb8bc99abd

commit_message:
fixed memcached is not restarted when config changed

That's because instead of start_container we need to
use recreate_or_restart_container in handler.

Change-Id: I3bb0a4c38b9024b2e2e26bfc06cb143bb5d35317
Signed-off-by: Pavel Glushchak <pglushchak@virtuozzo.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2fde95ca0846d4f4c94abf5993cd9469f6a4058a)

commit_message:
make yum fail on missing packages

By default yum skips missing packages. As a result built images may not
contain what we expect them to have (often found on non-x86
architectures).

There is an option to make it fail in same way as APT does in Debian
world. And this patch makes use of it so broken images just fail:

INFO:kolla.image.build.openstack-base:No package Percona-Server-shared-56 available.
INFO:kolla.image.build.openstack-base:Error: Not tolerating missing names on install, stopping.
INFO:kolla.image.build.openstack-base:
INFO:kolla.image.build.openstack-base:Removing intermediate container d5e506330b08
ERROR:kolla.image.build.openstack-base:Error'd with the following message

Closes-Bug: #1675401

Change-Id: Ib6b9e6b8cc216ce283cd043fa3600db7c0cc2a98
(cherry picked from commit d2c8372e99315d5071cca97d83a941f99e66dbd0)

Probably, but it's a backport. The fact that it didn't break any tests suggests that we just have a general lack of test coverage for this code."}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-10-17 19:03:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Is that OK?"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-10-18 16:48:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> If argvalue is a list, this will now break:
 > 
 > AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'split'
 >

Yes, argvalue comes from an earlier split call so it can't be a list."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-10-18 22:30:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9796, 'date': '2018-10-19 06:51:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-11-06 18:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Created a revert of this change as Id0834bd83b86eba2429bfdb6101907e7a6b2541f'}]

[{'created': '2018-10-17 15:49:36.000000000', 'message': "Config dict arguments.url must be a list

For memcache, arguments.url is assumed to be a list, this means
that the underlying memcache library could not handle a case where
a string (comma separated) was passed in. The idea is to force a
split on ',' in the special case of backend_argument=url:...
so that a list is passed to the backend.

Change-Id: I65afb46455423d7f96e17c471330c8d74dc17cac
Closes-Bug: #1743036
(cherry picked from commit 685a05edfef24cb2300df24aa3417ad0ecd2c2c2)

commit_message:
Config dict arguments.url must be a list

For memcache, arguments.url is assumed to be a list, this means
that the underlying memcache library could not handle a case where
a string (comma separated) was passed in. The idea is to force a
split on ',' in the special case of backend_argument=url:...
so that a list is passed to the backend.

Change-Id: I65afb46455423d7f96e17c471330c8d74dc17cac
Closes-Bug: #1743036
(cherry picked from commit 685a05edfef24cb2300df24aa3417ad0ecd2c2c2)

commit_message:
Config dict arguments.url must be a list

For memcache, arguments.url is assumed to be a list, this means
that the underlying memcache library could not handle a case where
a string (comma separated) was passed in. The idea is to force a
split on ',' in the special case of backend_argument=url:...
so that a list is passed to the backend.

Change-Id: I65afb46455423d7f96e17c471330c8d74dc17cac
Closes-Bug: #1743036
